qas.question: What combinations does unicode contain in normal use?
How is the latin small letter e represented in Unicode?
How is the accent added to the small latin e?
What precomposed character represents the small latin e with an accent?
What are inserted before a main character?
What cannot have multiple instances of diacritics?
What do applications have to implement?
What prevents redundancy in the ways you can make one character?
How is the capital letter e indicated in unicode?

context: Unicode includes a mechanism for modifying character shape that greatly extends the supported glyph repertoire. This covers the use of combining <b4_0>diacritical marks<b4_0/>. They are inserted after the main character. Multiple combining diacritics may be stacked over <b5_0>the same character<b5_0/>. Unicode also contains precomposed versions of <a0_0>most letter/diacritic combinations<a0_0/> in normal use. These make conversion to and from legacy encodings simpler, and allow applications to use Unicode as an internal text format without having to implement <b6_0>combining characters<b6_0/>. For example, é can be represented in Unicode as <a1_0><b8_0>U+0065<b8_0/><a1_0/> (LATIN SMALL LETTER E) followed by <a2_0>U+0301<a2_0/> (COMBINING ACUTE ACCENT), but it can also be represented as the precomposed character <a3_0>U+00E9<a3_0/> (LATIN SMALL LETTER E WITH ACUTE). Thus, in many cases, users have multiple ways of encoding the same character. To deal with this, Unicode provides <b7_0>the mechanism of canonical equivalence<b7_0/>.
